bestBHT.bht: When Jesus was transfigured, a voice from the cloud spoke, declaring Jesus as the beloved and chosen Son. This voice, like the one heard at Jesus' baptism, was that of the Father. The disciples were commanded to listen to Jesus, even when he prophesied his death, serving as a rebuke to Simon Peter and an instruction for all believers to heed Jesus' words. The actual words spoken were not in Greek but conveyed the idea of Jesus being both beloved and chosen. This divine proclamation from the cloud affirmed Jesus' identity as the Son of God.

Philip Schaff: My Son, my chosen one. The words were not spoken in Greek, and the actual word used might be translated into Greek by either of the terms, ‘beloved’ or ‘chosen.’
Archibald T. Robertson: Out of the cloud (εκ της νεφελης). This voice was the voice of the Father like that at the baptism of Jesus and like that near the end when the people thought it was a clap of thunder or an angel.

My son, my chosen (Hο υιος μου, ο εκλελεγμενος). So the best documents. These disciples are commanded to hear Jesus, God's Son, even when he predicts his death, a pointed rebuke to Simon Peter as to all.
These disciples are commanded to hear Jesus, God's Son, even when he predicts his death, a pointed rebuke to Simon Peter as to all.
John Gill: And there came, a voice out of the cloud,....

bhtAttempts.bht: When Jesus was transfigured, a voice from the cloud spoke, declaring Jesus as the beloved and chosen Son. This voice, like the one heard at Jesus' baptism, was that of the Father. The disciples were commanded to listen to Jesus, even when he prophesied his death, serving as a rebuke to Simon Peter and an instruction for all believers to heed Jesus' words. The actual words spoken were not in Greek but conveyed the idea of Jesus being both beloved and chosen. This divine proclamation from the cloud affirmed Jesus' identity as the Son of God.

When Jesus was transfigured, a voice from the cloud declared him as the beloved and chosen Son. This voice, similar to the one heard at Jesus' baptism, was that of the Father. The disciples were commanded to hear Jesus, even when he predicted his death. This rebuked Simon Peter and emphasized the importance of listening to Jesus' words. The original words spoken were not in Greek, but signified that Jesus was both beloved and chosen. This divine affirmation from the cloud confirmed Jesus' identity as the Son of God.

At the transfiguration, a voice from the cloud proclaimed Jesus as the beloved and chosen Son. This divine voice echoed the one heard at Jesus' baptism and emphasized the need to listen to Jesus. Despite predicting his death, Jesus' words were to be heeded by the disciples, a direct rebuke to Simon Peter and a universal instruction for all believers. Although not in Greek, the original words used conveyed the significance of Jesus being both beloved and chosen. This heavenly declaration solidified Jesus' identity as the Son of God.

At the transfiguration, a divine voice from the cloud proclaimed Jesus as the beloved and chosen Son. This voice, similar to the one heard at Jesus' baptism, carried the authority of the Father. The disciples were commanded to listen attentively to Jesus, even when he spoke of his impending death. This was a pointed rebuke to Simon Peter and a reminder for all believers to give heed to Jesus' words. Though not spoken in Greek, the original words indicated Jesus' status as both beloved and chosen. This heavenly declaration confirmed Jesus' identity as the Son of God.

During the transfiguration, a voice from the cloud affirmed Jesus as the beloved and chosen Son, echoing the Father's earlier declaration at Jesus' baptism. This divine proclamation instructed the disciples to listen exclusively to Jesus, even when he foretold his own death, serving as a rebuke to Simon Peter. The phrase used, not in Greek, conveyed the idea of Jesus being both beloved and chosen. This heavenly affirmation solidified Jesus' identity as the Son of God.
